subtitle: Thinking Allowed. Conversations on the leading edge of knowledge
and discovery with psychologist Jeffrey Mishlove.
Hello and welcome. I'm Jeffrey Mishlove. Our topic today is Unveiling the Secrets
of the Psyche. Pierre Janet, Sigmund Freud,
and Carl Jung. With me today is Adam Crabtree,
who's been a guest several times on New Thinking
Allowed in the past. Adam is a founding faculty
member at the Center for Training in Psychotherapy
based in Toronto. He is the author of many books,
including Multiple Man, Explorations in Possession, and Multiple Personality. From
Mesmer to Freud, Magnetic Sleep and the Roots of
Psychological Healing. He is a contributing author
to Irreducible Mind, Toward a Psychology for the
21st Century, and he is associate editor of Beyond
Physicalism, Toward Reconciliation of Science
and Spirituality. He is author of The Land of
Hypnagogia, and he has recently completed a
two-volume translation of Pierre Janet's classic
book, Psychological Automatism. Adam is based in
Toronto, and now I'll switch over to the internet
video. Welcome, Adam. What a pleasure to be with
you again. It's great to be with you also, Jeff.
Congratulations on this translation, I believe
the first time, into the English language of
Janet's masterpiece on Psychological Automatism. It's been a long time coming.
Indeed it has. I'm glad you're enjoying it, Jeff.
But why don't we begin with a little biographical
background on Janet. I think even though he's
acknowledged as one of the founders of Western
psychology, and particularly the psychology of
the unconscious and Western psychotherapy, his name
isn't remembered the way we think of Freud and Jung.
No, it is not. When I began working as a
psychotherapist over 50 years ago, nobody heard
about Janet. That was in the 1960s, in the late
60s. Nobody had heard of Janet, and it was all
Freud. If you were psychodynamic, that is, if you
worked with the unconscious, it was Freud or a bit
of Jung, but Janet was basically unknown. And it's
only really in the 1980s, the mid-1980s, that people
started to become aware again of Janet, because
he's always been around, if you wanted to find him.
But to actually bring him into the forefront of
thinking about psychotherapy, that was about the
mid-1980s. And I connect that with the fact that so
much more was being found out about dissociation,
dissociative disorders, traumatic effects
within dissociation, and multiple personality.
Those things are all really being investigated
very hotly, you might say, at that time. And I
recall that one whole issue of the Journal of
the American, Journal of Clinical Hypnosis,
was about Janet in 1986. So, to me, that was
a sign, that was sort of the point, where a
significant shift happened. And I had known about him before, because I was studying
multiple personality, and I, of course, came
across him then, but not as a popular figure.
It was in 1980s, that I was very much involved
also with writing and working with multiple
personality. So, even more for me, I was gratified
to see that people were starting to notice him,
because I knew that he was the person who had
the greatest, the most important and effective
system for understanding how dissociation works, how dissociative disorder develops,
and what multiple personality actually is. So,
I knew him, but I knew I could read some French.
And I knew that almost none of my colleagues
could read French, which meant they knew nothing
about Janet, and I couldn't recommend anything
to them, because very little of him was in
English. So, I had, it had been on my mind for
quite some time to try to find a way to get
Janet translated into English. And I talked to a friend in Belgium, Onno van der Hart,
who was also very much aware of Janet, and
important in developing ideas of dissociation.
And we tried some years ago to get a translation
going, but we couldn't. And so, finally,
a few years ago, he and I talked, and he asked if I would translate it.
I hadn't thought about doing that, because I
thought that was too big a job, frankly. But
I decided, yeah, okay. And I, then I came across or met my translation partner,
whose name is Sarah Osei-Bonsu, who's a wonderful
partner in translation. And we started doing it.
And we, it took us about a year, year and a half
to do the translation. And now it's available
from Rutledge. Unfortunately, I don't know if
it's, to me, it's sort of strange that Rutledge
published it in two volumes rather than one,
because it was one volume originally. And the
title that they gave it was the titles of the two
halves, which is not the original title of the
book, which was Psychological Automatism. Yes,
I want to go back to Genet, however. I think
most people don't know, for example, that he preceded both Jung and Freud.
Oh, yes, absolutely. He was the one who opened
the door to understanding the unconscious,
the door that was first opened by Puysegur. But
he's the one who really delved through that door
and began exploring from a psychological and from a psychotherapeutic point of view,
what Puysegur had brought into view. The Marquis de Puysegur, in 1784, wrote a book
called his Memoirs of Working with Artificial
Somnambulism. And that was the work that really
affected Genet. Genet, in 1924, looking back,
said, those are my roots. My roots are in animal
magnetism and artificial somnambulism, which started with Puysegur in 1784. And he
had studied that work, and he saw how the awareness that there's a second self within
individuals, a second self different from their
normal self, that is always operating in their
unconscious or what he came to call a subconscious
mind. Well, I know we've done a previous interview
on Puysegur and his connection to mesmer and
the important work he did, particularly the
important work he did in showing that what we
now call the hypnotic state was conducive to
clairvoyance. So I'm going to link to that earlier
interview in case our viewers are interested in
it. They can look in the upper right hand corner
of their screen and most viewers will be able to
link directly to that interview on Puysegur. He's
a very, very important figure. But in terms of
20th century psychology of the unconscious, we think of Jung and we think of Freud and
Genet gets forgotten, but he was really the
inspiration to both of those men. That's right.
You're absolutely right. It's really in the last
few years Genet has actually been remembered and
it is coming to the fore. He has talked about
whenever anybody discusses dissociation from
a depth point of view, Genet will be remembered
now. That wasn't true a few years ago.
So there's a definite progress there. And I
think another key factor about Genet is that
the therapy he developed, which was quite effective,
is based on what we would now call hypnosis.
And for reasons of their own, both Freud and Jung
started in that area, but they abandoned hypnosis
for methods that they developed. That's very,
very true. They abandoned hypnosis. I'm not sure
if this is true or not, but I have read that Freud
found it awkward and difficult to use hypnosis,
didn't feel comfortable with it. And Jung was
working so deeply with the collective unconscious
that he really did not pay too much attention
to artificial somnambulism or hypnosis.
Artificial somnambulism was the term that
Genet was using in his day. He used that and
it began, that term started with the Marquis de
Puysegur, who really learned animal magnetism
from Mesmer. He learned animal magnetism from Mesmer and when he began practicing it
for using Mesmer's healing passes or movements of the hands over the body,
some of the people he was working with went
into states that he did not recognize and that
Mesmer said nothing about. These were states where they seemed to be asleep,
but they were actually able to communicate with
him, speak with him, and they were able to hear
him and understand and also follow his
instructions as he was working on healing them.
He noted this state that was very unusual and so he
started to pursue an investigation of this state.
He would ask the person that he was using the
magnetic healing on what they were experiencing,
what they were thinking, and if they had
anything to say about their illness or about the
treatment of their illness or the course of
their illness. And he found that this state,
in this state, they could say a great deal and
actually they were able to do what he called
seeing clearly or clairvoyance. That was the term that he used. And through that
clairvoyant faculty, identify their illness and identify treatment for their illness
and the course that their illness would take before it had run its course.
This is what you would call a trance state. It is
a trance state in my understanding of the term,
yes. It's a state where a person is put in touch
with the depths of themselves that they cannot
ordinarily reach in their usual waking state.
And he recognized that depth almost immediately.
He had attended a, it was a sort of a lecture,
a series of lectures by Mesmer that taught him
how to use Mesmer's approach. And when he used it,
he immediately saw that what he was discovering
was something more than Mesmer had been aware of.
And that was what he labeled magnetic somnambulism
and artificial somnambulism. Now, to give
our viewers a sense of the time, I know that
Mesmer was a contemporary of the American founding fathers. He was an 18th century
figure. Puysegur was a bit younger. He was a bit younger, yes.
They were almost, they were very close in age.
But Puysegur was 30 years old when he went to
Mesmer's seminar, teaching seminar. He was 30 years
old. And when you think about that fact alone,
that's really something because such a young
man making such a huge discovery. But anyway,
the American Revolution had already happened.
And the French society was being stirred up
towards their own revolution, which would happen
in 1789. And so that was the atmosphere in which
Puysegur was working and within which he made
his discovery. There was a lot of turmoil.
And there was a lot of, it was also a time where what we might call amateur science,
which was really the science of the time, but
we would call amateurs because it was done
not so much in universities, but in different
people's private laboratories. That was at its
height. And it was shifting now to the scientific
discoveries and what today we would call
not amateur, but professional science. All that
was occurring at the very same time as Puysegur
was making his discovery. Which would have
been in the late 18th century, maybe the early
19th century. And as I recall, Genet was born in 1859.
59, correct. Yes. And he died in 1946. He
lived a long life and he wrote a lot of things.
And so, but there was a gap of close to a
hundred years between Puysegur's discovery and
Genet's beginning to work with the same ideas and implement them.
That's right. And there's another hundred years
gap to our beginning to recognize the importance
of Genet. So we're having century movements here, century by century.
And as you were saying, Genet used the same language as Puysegur, artificial
somnambulism, which means sleepwalking. It does. And the reason he called it that was
this state that he discovered that I just
briefly described very much resembled what people
understood sort of in the folk thinking of
the time. They called it somnambulism, that is
sleepwalking. And what today we still call
sleepwalking. I know at least one of my children
was a sleepwalker when he was very young. But sleepwalking is a part of natural
developments of some people that usually they
sleepwalk when they're children. It often
passes away and they stop when they're adults.
I was a sleepwalker myself. And I think the last
time I remember doing it, I was in university.
So there was this natural thing that people
knew about. And he saw that there were
important ways this discovery of this new state,
this uncharted state of somnambulism was rightly
named somnambulism, but artificial somnambulism,
because it was brought about not by chance, by
nature, by sort of unpredictable circumstances
of life, but rather he had a technique where he
could bring it about, make it happen at will.
And if you think of the power of that step of
being able to bring it about at will, and then
study it and repeat it and bring it about
in different subjects as an object of study,
and developing ideas around that state. This
was a huge step forward in the understanding
of the dynamics of the human psyche.
Genet also reported, at least in his early
career, clairvoyance associated with this state.
Yes, he did. And he, in the book we translated
his, I'm thinking about how he used this,
he had a couple of chapters where he talks a great
deal about spiritualism and about mediumship.
And about clairvoyance as it is, as it exists
in the practice of spiritualism of his time.
And so this was a familiar term to him. But unfortunately, Genet was hesitant,
not to accept the phenomena of spiritualism,
but hesitant to accept their explanation of it.
That's not unfortunate in itself. But he did have a kind of skepticism that I think
made him lean certain ways when he was working
out his theories that narrowed his view of what
psychology needed to explain and how the psyche,
how the depths of the psyche show themselves.
I think it's fair to say that Jung and Freud both
also struggled with this issue. They were both
fascinated by the occult and the esoteric and
things such as clairvoyance. But at the same time,
they're trying to establish psychotherapy as a profession, as a science. And I think
all three of these individuals were afraid of alienating their colleagues.
Particularly Freud, absolutely. Jung was a
little more bold, I would say. But Jung followed
his nose. He followed where experiences led him,
much more than Freud. Freud did that too, of
course. But there were certain doors that he said
should be kept closed because it would be dangerous
for the development of his system and of his
ideas if he was associated with things having
to do with the paranormal. Yeah, that's unfortunate
because, at least to my way of thinking, you really
aren't going to understand normal consciousness
until you have a grip on the paranormal side of
things. Absolutely, I agree with you. And absolutely, I have to give credit to Genet,
who said, we need to listen to these experiences
that spiritualists have. They're not making them
up. They're not faking them. These are real
psychological experiences that can tell us things
about the subconscious mind and how dissociation
works in individuals. So, he was open to the data.
It's his sort of almost fear of committing to any
sort of explanation, deeper explanation for the
data. That's where he hesitated. And, you know,
he had a good way out. He just said, I'm not a
philosopher, so I'm not really qualified to
comment on these things. But I'm glad to use the
data that it's producing. Now, you've used the term
dissociation many times already in our conversation.
And I know our viewers will have a sense of what
multiple personality is. But let's see if we can
define dissociation a little more clearly.
Yes. Dissociation is the ability that we have
to separate pieces of experience, one from the
other. We can experience, have an experience in
one situation, and it's a part of our lives,
and it's part of our memories. And then we go to
another situation, very different situation, and
we might be very different in the way we handle
that situation. And our memory for the first
situation might be sort of vague because we're
now in a different state. So, we have this ability
to produce different states that are separable
from each other. It's natural. It's not a
pathology. It's only a problem when the separation
takes place because a defensive maneuver is taking
place within the subconscious of the person,
where a particular set of experiences is
associated with trauma. And so, to protect oneself
from experiencing or re-experiencing the trauma,
that situation is separated off. And that's what
dissociation is. It's the separation process.
One of the things, one of the ways that I
agree with everything Janet said about that, but
one of the ways I go, I don't know if I'm going to
say beyond or wider, my view is wider than Janet's,
and that is that I believe that dissociation
is not inevitably linked to pathology. Really,
Janet thought it was. And this led to a lot of
sort of, I think, rigid approaches to his theory,
where he has to explain everything in terms of
pathology. I think that's an unfortunate mistake,
where I myself took another step, let's say,
beyond Janet's ideas, was to say, was to talk
about trances or artificial somnambulism states,
but I call them trances, as something that's a
part of normal human experience and experiences
that we have in everyday life. So, I've taken
a lot of the ideas of Janet and spread them
with a wider focus, a wider scope. And I think
that's the way it really is. I think that
multiplicity, human multiplicity, is normal.
And it's only pathological when it has to deal
with unresolved elements of experience in a
person's life. Well, I gather that while Freud
and Jung gave some passing reference to the
issue of dissociation and multiple personality,
for the most part, they both glossed over its
implications. Yes, I agree with that. I think that
this is a problem with, and you see it in a
sort of a dispute that took place between Jung
and Freud. Freud said that we have only one consciousness, and that consciousness
is like a searchlight that we direct now on this set of mental activities,
and now a different set of mental activities. But consciousness itself is not
associated with those mental activities
necessarily. He said that mental events are in
the first instance unconscious, and then we make
them conscious by directing our attention to it.
And this is so different from Genet, who said
all mental units that we have have consciousness
associated with them, and often they have also
each one a sense of identity. They become like
a secondary self that exists in the subconscious
mind, a secondary personality, a secondary
identity. And there can be many of those secondary
selves operating in the subconscious mind without
our realizing it. And this gave Genet a
tremendously powerful system for dealing with
dissociative disorders, and specifically multiple
personality, which is on the extreme end of the
spectrum of dissociative disorders, where the
dissociated identities actually take on a life
of their own periodically or cyclically within
one individual. That's multiple personality in
the full sense of the word, and that's the
extreme end of dissociative identity disorder.
I guess it might be fair to say that Carl Jung, with his theory of archetypes,
comes a little bit closer to Genet's model of the
psyche. Indeed, and his idea of complexness is
very close to Genet's notion of these individual identities within a person,
where those identities for Jung build around
certain archetypes. He says they have an
archetypal core. His complexes have an archetypal core, but they are individual,
and each individual has many complexes, and those complexes have a feeling of identity,
like they are personalities. He learned this, I
think, largely from Genet, because he studied with
Genet, and he very much appreciated Genet.
Unlike Freud, he felt a kindred spirit in Genet.
I gather that Freud, in his early years, acknowledged the debt he owed to Genet,
but a conflict developed between them. Yes,
the conflict was formulated this way by Genet.
Genet said that Freud came along and saw what
he, Genet, was doing and thought it was good,
but then he began doing the same thing and giving
the impression that he was the first to do it.
So, it was a matter of priority. Who was the first
for developing these ideas, having to do with what
Jung called, or sorry, what Genet called the
subconscious, and what Freud called the unconscious.
Genet, I think, would say that there's very little
original in Freud. Very little he did not get from
himself, and this was something that was argued
out in conferences and in articles and journals
and so forth. I wouldn't say that it was ever
resolved. Freud took offense at the idea that
Genet basically claimed that Freud was plagiarizing
him. Yes, that's basically what he was doing,
what he was claiming, and Freud, indeed, did take offense, yes.
That developed, you might say, a major split in the psychodynamic movement.
Yes, it was a split in sort of in the loyalties, but also, I wonder how much.
It explained the fact that Freud simply could
not accept the business of multiple identities
in one individual, or dissociative parts, let's
say, that maybe that would seem like too much of a
giving over of credit to Genet, which he was not happy to do.
It also strikes me that when it comes to the
philosophical question about the ontological
reality of spirit entities, autonomous spirit
entities, that the idea of autonomous subpersonalities
is very attractive. Well, it is indeed, and I know that you know this because I've
talked about it on your programs, but Frederick Myers and Genet were friends,
and they worked together with psychological experiments, but there were also ways that
Myers saw Genet's approach, as I do, as somewhat too limited in certain areas.
And Myers had a view of individual personalities that might make up a set of
dissociative personalities, and spiritualist
entities. He said they come from the same place.
Now, he wasn't ready to say that all spiritual entities are simply dissociative
identities coming from trauma, but he recognized
that some of those identities are that, rather
than independently existing entities. But Myers
had no problem, if the evidence was there for him,
he had no problem accepting the fact that there
are, or can be, entities that understood the way
spiritualists do, that they are independent,
that they are the, you might say, the soul of an
individual that is there also, and can survive
death. So, there are many ways in which Myers
and Genet helped each other and agreed with each other, but in that area, that area of
the nature of these part personalities, these
secondary personalities, they had differences.
We should talk a bit about the form of
psychotherapy that Genet developed. I'm under
the impression it must be very similar to the
psychotherapy that you practice, and that you
think it's really a better model for psychotherapy
than either Jungian or Freudian approaches.
Yes, I do. I think that Genet had such great,
there was such great power in his ideas,
that he's affected by thinking very much, so that
when I began thinking about and then writing about
the history of hypnosis and the nature of
hypnosis, I was certainly much affected by Genet's
ideas. But I thought it was possible to be more
inclusive in understanding that altered state of
consciousness, that alternate consciousness
that we have, that secondary self that we have,
that it could be more broadly understood, and
that therapy, if it would take that into account,
could become much more effective. And what I
mean is this. If individuals realize that they
naturally dissociate in their lives, that dissociation is a part of living, and it's
something that actually makes living possible.
If we had everything that we know and feel coming
in on us at once, we would be very confused. We
could hardly live. So we have to separate off
pieces of existence from each other. And that's
something that it helps for clients to know.
And that then gives them the opportunity to take
a further step of saying, you can separate off
pieces of existence in such a way that they're
no longer known to you, no longer a part of your
awareness, but still affecting you. And that
a good part of therapy is to deal with those
dissociated aspects or parts, and to find out
how they originated and see how to heal them.
So I think that this is a very effective way
to do therapy. And for that reason, in my
work, I often use hypnosis, or you might say
artificial somnambulism. But I understand it
more broadly, as I've explained. And so I've come
in the latter decades of my work, I've come to
realize that when we do therapy at all, if the two people sitting together in a room,
speaking about the difficulties that the client
is having, both the therapist and the client
go into a trance state. Both of us sort of remove distractions of other things,
the environment and the rest of our lives, to
concentrate on this limited matter of concern
that the client brings in. And that is what I see as the very definition of hypnosis.
And that is, it's a state of high concentration
and obliviousness to other things that are not
a part of that focus, which then enables the
unconscious or the subconscious to bring forward
elements that are ordinarily not available.
And bringing forward those things can also make
it possible to heal whatever of them might be causing trouble or inner conflict, pain.
I'm under the impression, Adam, that outside of
the therapeutic context, the idea of the power
of these subpersonalities can be a way for people
to get in touch with their own hidden genius.
I've seen, for example, people under hypnosis who
have a certain amount of musical talent could be
put into a trance state and told to compose a
piano concerto, for example, in the style of
Mendelssohn. And they can sit down and without any
rehearsal or any thought, they just spontaneously
compose a piano concerto. Yes, I've heard of
those people too. And I know that some of them,
there are controversies around them, of course,
as you know, that if a person does that,
if they produce some creative piece that's
very much in the style of some known musician,
if that musician has departed and is no longer
with us, sometimes it is felt that this represents
that individual taking over an aspect of
the person and sort of playing through them.
That's like a spiritualist way of looking at
this. A non-spiritualist way of looking at this,
I suppose, a way that perhaps Janet would look
at it would be, well, you know, they've heard
the compositions of this person. This is something
they've absorbed into their subconscious mind,
and they have a talent for translating such feelings and memories of hearing pieces
into something that very much reflects or
resembles what they have heard and the style
of the people that they have had that experience with.
But there's a further thing about creativity
I'd like to say right here, and that is that
it is one of the reasons that Myers and Janet
so early said we must not look at human beings
as having only one mind, and that is what we,
the conscious mind, what we think of ourselves
as being. You can't explain human experience
in its depth in terms of one mind. We have many
minds, said Myers. This is Myers now. Janet'd
say at least two minds, and that means that there
are intelligent and even creative things happening
outside of the awareness of the person in their
ordinary state, and it's that ferment that's
happening on a subconscious level that can
produce creative products, and that if you're
going to explain creativity, Janet and Myers would
say, you better not try to do it with just
thinking that everything we know is conscious,
that we have only the conscious mind. There
are subconscious minds, and these can be the
sources, or let's put it this way, their existence
can be a way of explaining how creative products
seem often to come from somewhere else. They
seem to be, or in the case of Mozart describing
his experience with creating music, they seem that you're hearing them
fully completed, and Mozart said his great strength was his
musical memory. He could hear something and then write it down.
That was what he was doing, but he was hearing something already existing, that
I should say there are many
not only musicians, but painters, writers, and other creative
people who feel the same way, who experience the same way.
It's not just a philosophical idea that makes them think this way.
This is the way they experience creative productions,
that they come from somewhere else, and they can't
explain why they took this particular form, but the great creators of the world
simply let that whatever is there come through
them, rather than preventing it, rather than
saying, I don't understand this, I can't, I'm
not going to accept it, rather than they become
something like channels for this. You know, Hoagy
Carmichael, who I've become very interested in
recently, he wrote something, he was asked
to write, he was asked to come into a class,
university class, to talk about songwriting.
Hoagy Carmichael, for those who don't know,
was one of the great songwriters of the 20th century, American, grew up in Indiana,
who started writing songs when he was in his
early 20s, and wrote many songs that most people
will recognize, and they don't know that they were written by Hoagy Carmichael.
Stardust, for instance, or The Nearness of You, there are so many songs that he wrote,
great songs that were hits. Now, what he
wrote in response to being asked to talk about
this to a class, he said, I won't be able to make them, unfortunately,
but let me say this for the people in the class.
When you, the song is already there, and it's
lying there in the keys, and it's waiting for
you to discover it. Well, he was a piano player,
see, so that's the way he would put it, it's in
the keys. And just let it come, find it in the
keys, and when you find it, let it take its own
course. Don't stop it, don't inhibit it in any
way, just let it take its own course. And he says,
and if you're writing a song where someone has already written the words, he said,
speak the words and use the tones or the relationship of tones when you speak it
in your feeling, bring that into the feeling of
writing as the song develops. So, he had this
sense, something was happening through him, and
he was just sort of the, what would you say,
he had the technical side of it, ready to be
able to put it into words, or words and music.
It seems very similar to Michelangelo talking
about the statue was already in the marble.
Yes, it's very much like that, yeah. So,
what you're suggesting, though, is that this,
that we all have some part of ourselves of which
we are totally unaware, and it has the potential
for genius. Absolutely, and that it's ingenious
that we see almost most clearly the depth of the
human psyche. The people who are able actually
to translate that and let it come through,
tell us a story of, or tell us, paint a
picture, you might say, of the human psyche,
and the depth of the human psyche. I believe
that it's an unfortunate mistake that,
okay, I'm going to be a little critical here.
It's an unfortunate mistake that psychoanalysis
has become so powerful a force in our
understanding of ourselves. I think it's also
very fortunate that it did. The ideas there did
become part of our culture, but it's unfortunate
that it has become so powerful, and I see it
sort of struggling to hang on to its power
in terms of explanatory systems for the human
psyche. I see that it has, wants to remain,
psychoanalysis wants to remain in a position
of preponderance in culture, the culture that
has to do with psychology and with psychotherapy.
And, in my mind, psychoanalysis, and also like
Genet, don't go to the greatest depths of the
human psyche. The greatest depths, we're still
discovering what they are, and one of the places
where we are discovering the greater depths of
the human psyche is precisely in the creative
people, in music, in the arts. There we see
something that we can't yet put into words, into
a system. We can't put it into a philosophy,
because it's beyond philosophy. Whatever is there in the depths producing all this,
you can never exhaust in words or through
theories. It can only be at this time of our
development or our evolution. It could only be
really, in any way adequately felt, is in the arts
more than anywhere else. That's my belief in it.
Well, I guess it's fair to say, to his credit,
that Freud brought out the idea of our hidden
aggression, our hidden sexual drives, the things
that are unacceptable to society. Jung emphasized
the shadow, the dark side, that in order to get
to this creative potential, one needs to sometimes
move through the shadow. Absolutely. I completely
agree with you, Jeffrey. I certainly don't want

I see elements of the attempt to gain predominance
or to have power, rather than simply elucidating
and letting others profit from that. I had
this experience many years ago when my sister
was graduating from the chiropractic school.
The person who was giving the talk at the school

once you're graduating now, but you have to

the process of learning about chiropractic. But
remember, read only those books that are approved
by the American Chiropractic Association. And I thought, okay, this is what happens.
The chiropractors have always been on the fringe, right? And once they start feeling
sort of accepted, then they want to exercise
power. And I think that's what happens. The great
discoveries are fringe, because they happen outside of the systems that are in power.
But once that new wonderful discovery comes to some kind of fruition in society,
there's a tendency to want to take power through
it. And that's where anything can become a
rigidity, can become frozen. Although at
one time, it may have been wonderfully free.
I feel the same way about parapsychology, as
a matter of fact, Adam. I feel that one of the

that are too far out even for the
parapsychologists. Yes. I understand what you're
saying. I see, know examples of that myself.
Absolutely. I think it can happen with anything
that has some real value, and comes from something really deep in individuals,
when in its first stages, it's closest to the
arts. And then it starts to become systematized.
And then it becomes rigidified. And then the
matter of taking power seems like it's the
logical next step. And almost maybe it happens

to the universe, because maybe it stems back to an
ancient terror of the demonic. Oh, yes. Yes. I

when you look into the abyss, don't forget the

In other words, if you look at our depth as an
